description:
Honestly my favorite place to go to for a quick lunch in Chinatown! The owners and the workers are all very nice as well! During lunch time, their portions are huge. However, dinner time, they skimp a lot on the meat portions, and give you loads of rice which is a minus. I usually get the salt and pepper chicken wings, beef chow fun, or Mongolian beef with rice.

Beef chow fun: 5/5 
Great flavors, perfectly cooked! I usually order this with no  green onions and onions. 

Mongolian rice: 4.5/5
I love eating this dish, since it has a little kick of spice in it, but it's a little greasy for me as well.. Although, the flavors are great.

Salt and pepper chicken: 5/5 
This is a must, the fried chicken here is so good for Asian style! They give you a really good portion for the order as well!
author: Elsa W.

description:
Note:  Cash only restaurant

This restaurant is unassuming and simple in looks, but the food is quite tasty.  No matter what you plan to order, add an order of the salted chicken wings. They say they're spicy on the menu, but I'd say they're only spicy if you eat the jalapeño chunks tossed in with them.  The skin is perfectly crisp, with no chewy/slimy/soggy parts of skin and the wings were meaty. We also had a plate of green beans w/ minced pork and a soup.  One soup order was enough for the 4 of us to each have a cup.  This place is perfect for ordering family style.  We were pleased by all the food.

If you are a soda drinker, know that you're just ordering a chilled can of soda.

Bonus:  They have a bathroom!
author: Andrea S.

description:
This is my favorite kind of Chinese restaurant! this is the kind of place the older more traditional Chinese customers like to go, no fancy table cloths or fancy dishes, very basic old diner style restaurant, it's a great place to take your whole family for  excellent food and dining experience, very reasonable prices, good service, the waitress are very attentive and helpful, this is not one of those fancy tourist trap type places, more of a local hole in the wall, Hong Kong  / Canton style.

The menu has a very good selection with lots of choices / variety, something for everyone, they have a lunch counter for single diners to grab a quick lunch, and tables for larger groups

I like the atmosphere , it feels like that old chinatown place you grew up with, the decor has "character" a homestyle feel

Tuesdays is Prime rib dinner day.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
Capital Restaurant delivers really solid Cantonese cooking in a no-frills cash-only Chinatown storefront. This is well-executed home-style cooking that's not too salty or greasy. 
Don't forget: Cash only
author: Quaker W.

description:
I've always liked Capital Restaurant.  A Chinatown classic that's been around for years - often with a mixed crowd of locals and travelers.  

Always consistently good food at reasonable prices.  What I like is the restaurant's flexibility ... we always order "low salt and low oil" and they are always happy to accommodate.  

You can't go wrong with any of their dishes: Chow Fun for lunch; Fried Rice; or a full family style dinner with entrees and steamed live fish.  

The winner dishes here are:
Fried Chicken Wing
Wor Wonton Soup
Minced Meat egg tofu
Steamed Live Seabass

Waitresses are efficient and friendly.  There often a short line but the line moves quick.

5-Star for the overall value!
author: Winnie W.

description:
Food is delicious, service is ehhhh.

Workers tends to treat tourist and white folks with better service ( sucking up), possibly in hopes to get more $$$$.

Anyways, now to talk about the food.
Food is bomb, it taste so good, their fried chicken wings are very famous here in the city but i still prefer San Tung Chicken Wings any day! ( Bigger and more tasty)

You can definitely taste the quality in the food and the portions are alot! Love it! More food to eat for the $$$. I really love their pea spouts, lamb clay pots and spareribs and of course their chicken wings.
author: Christopher G.

description:
After a shopping trip in Chinatown, my sister and I wanted to get some late lunch.  Our favorite to go places have closed over the past couple of years as the costs of running a restaurant have increased annually.  The latest being the minimum wage increase in the City.
 
Since we were on Clay St., I saw Capital and having heard from others about this restaurant, we decided to give it a try. As you walk in, the layout is the classic Chinatown diner set-up with a counter in front with tables for four on the sides and larger round tables in the middle.
 
Checking out the menu, they had a lunch specials along with a good selection of dishes. With dinner a couple hours away, we decided to opt for something on the lighter side, so we each ordered wonton noodle soup. We asked, but they did not have the wider egg noodle, so we stuck with the standard thin egg noodles. There were 6 won tons with a small portion of noodles in a flavorful broth.  I was expecting shrimp or shrimp/pork won tons, but these were classic all pork. Relative to the price, they were ok and nothing special. I still prefer shrimp won tons.
 
It appears Capital is known for its salt and pepper chicken wings. If I come back, I will opt for something other than wonton noodle soup and might give the wings a try.
author: Al L.

description:
being the majority of Chinese in San Francisco are Cantonese why is it so difficult to find a really good Cantonese Fried Rice? ..
I have yet to find a good "wok hei" Cantonese fried rice anywhere in San Francisco.
I'm confused, but I'll move on.
luckily, I also ordered another item in case that I'm being disappointed again and again with my search for wok hei Cantonese fried rice.

I ordered Capital Spare Ribs.
they are so good, succulent, sweet but not overly sweet.
I'm glad that I ordered this.

I like this restaurant.
the people are nice, the menu is good, the feeling is very homey.
I will absolutely come here again if I'm in the mood for Chinese food.
author: Rudy H.

description:
This is my family's go to chinese restaurant. I've been coming here since I could walk...probably. And I will keep coming back until I can't. 

Don't leave this place without trying the salt and pepper wings. They're the best I've ever had, and super crispy and piping hot when they're fresh. Just don't burn your tongue. 

My other favorite is the fish, mushroom, and tofu clay pot. They also have seafood and other clay pots.

The menu has many choices, and I haven't disliked anything. 

Cash only!
author: Corinna T.

description:
Anything with fried chicken wings, especially salt-n-peppa wings...is a must try for me! especially if they're advertising it on their windows and menu. While walking in Chinatown in SF, I figured, I am hungry and need some good comfort food. Walked right on by and saw their chicken and other menu items on their window. Dang it looked good huh?

I will say, the place is small but cozy. I loved how they have this "bar area" where you can sit and eat, especially if you're eating alone. I walked in and was immediately greeted and sat at the bar area. I ordered their salt-n-peppa wings and looked at the lunch menu and got their lunch combo of rice and pork with beans. 

I will say that the wings are exactly what you want: crispity crispy skin, super hot, beautifully cooked, and nicely seasoned with salt. I will add--there is nothing special about these wings. I know, I know, I'm sorry, but what is so special? The salt they sprinkle on top? I'm sorry, but we have better places here in Washington. I will definitely say it is worth trying to try, to say you had it, but I will definitely show you better if you ever come here. Don't get me wrong, the chicken was tender and juicy, but didn't have anything special to the flavor. The frying of the wings were perfect though. They gave me hella wings though--the serving came with at least 10 wings. I could not even eat them all.

The green beans and spare ribs were good. Loved the right amounts of soy sauce and oyster sauce and I appreciated how tender the ribs were. Definitely a great lunch option! Both dishes were less than $20. Pretty good deal for the food portions. Food came out fast and everyone was so friendly here. You can tell people love coming here though. During lunch hour it was filling up with locals. I would definitely come here again if I needed to and when I'm here again. Free soup in the meal (i'd pass on this, nothing notable to say). Cash only!
author: Tan Lo S.

description:
The food here was okay, but overall the service was slow and I came here with too high expectations of their chicken wings that unfortunately weren't met. 

Their salt and pepper chicken wings ($10.50) were hot and crispy and fresh out of the fryer, and the meat inside was tender and juicy. However, I didn't think they were seasoned in any special way that made them stand out above other chicken wings I have had.

The capital spareribs ($11.95) were fried and covered in a tasty sauce, but I got a couple very fatty pieces that tasted kind of off, almost as if the meat had started to go a little bad. 

The sautéed green beans with minced pork ($11.95) were quite good and very flavorful, but the house fried rice ($10.95) was just okay. 

Overall, this place was similar to a typical Chinese restaurant but wasn't exceptional.
author: Amy C.

description:
I was craving chicken wings for lunch so I decided to walk to my usual chinese place, hole in the wall , in the Stockton/Washington area, but as soon as I turned on Clay, I saw this place with pictures on the window. Saw the Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings. So I had to try them.
Their a bit pricey but man! They are so good! 
They fry them when you order so it's piping hot when you get it. 
I usually get it to go. I eat them as I walk back to my office.
author: Randee D.

description:
Yum! Walked by and the menu photos posted in their window caught my eye. We got:
Beef stew with dried bean curd stick (lunch special version, so less of the stew and with rice included). Disclaimer I forgot to take photos first so the portions are bigger than pictured!
And Fukkian style egg tofu - fried medallions of super soft silky egg tofu, topped with a saucy gravy full of diced meats, seafoods, and bits of green veggie. 

They also gave us a soup with winter melon and carrot chunks (maybe this was part of the lunch special?)
author: Windy Q.

description:
Very charming Chinese restaurant that made me feel like I was in Hong Kong. The chicken wings that everyone comes here for are fantastic. Super crispy and juicy! Everything else was good too. Capital was everything I was hoping the nearby Han Wo would be but significantly better. 

Make sure you stop by an ATM before dining here though. They're cash only and despite being classified as a one dollar sign restaurant, my tab for four people came out to over $100.
author: Charles L.

description: Ordered a noodle to go. When I got the order, I was so shock. They put all the noodle and soup in ONE container, instead of separate containers. As most people expected, my noodle is so f... up after I got home. They can't even handle to-go order correctly. The noodle just taste so horrible.
author: Eat-Around T.

description:
Wings, wings and more wings!! This place should distribute these things by the truck load. The jalapeños mixed with the perfect savoryness and crunch makes it worth the trip.  And again, this place actually makes other dishes that are super tasty as well,  try any of their rice plates!  I'm a fan of their food.  Service was fine.

Food 4.5
Service 3
Overall 4
author: Patrick C.

description: I came in and was seated  right away. I ordered the appetizer Capital plate and the salt and pepper spareribs. When I  presented to the waiter my coupon code  from Yelp  he said they no longer honor it. The food was pleasant but what made the meal was the staff. They were on top of everything  and very helpful with my questions. I  would visit them again  or order delivery.
author: Jeremiah M.

description: Friendly servers, not typically like other restaurants in the area. Food is ok. Location is strategic in Chinatown. Price is average for sitting place to eat in.
author: Adam M.

description: I had this place bookmarked on Yelp. Someone I was chatting with dropped this in conversation regarding its chicken wingz. My mom said she was coming here today for the wings. We were doing some grocery shopping in Chinatown. I had never been here and had the wings before. After glancing at the menu, I realized it was mix of American favorites and authentic food. A lot of rice dishes, noodle dishes, etc. And also, it's a not a cheap place. Every dish may be at least $11, but no place is cheap these days all over SF. I wanted the hot and sour soup and beef and broccoli with rice. We got the chicken wings and also egg shrimp noodle as well. It was all very good. Actually I didn't try the egg shrimp noodle. It's not groundbreaking food, but a decent meal in Chinatown. People in the know rave about the wings, but actually they are not the best I have ever had. Tasty enough though.
author: Denise C.

description:
So.. Your typical hole in a wall kind of restaurant. Grandpa's favorite, so of course, we come here often. 
Service is ok.. food is what mom would be cooking at home type of food. Comfort food. Their speciality is their chicken wings ( salt and spicy). Very tasty but of course, I can only have 1. I can't handle spicy food. My other favorite is a clay pot dish. The melon and vermicelli noodles. Typical comfort food.
author: S C.

description:
Came here specifically for the fried salt and pepper chicken wings from a friend's recommendation. I had no idea they had a "famous" reputation for their wings as I never heard anything from local food reviews or Yelp. Nonetheless, I got an order and must say: CRISPIEST CHICKEN WING EVER!

In terms of skin texture, hands down the best amongst any chicken wing in the city. How about taste? Mostly just salty with a subtle dose of heat. Also a plus that they aren't too greasy. You get 12 wings per order I believe. Decent portion for the price. They give good sized wings. 

Be warned, Cash only. Service is pretty horrible too even for Chinese restaurant standards. 

Food: 4.25/5
Value: 3.5/5
Service: 2/5
Overall: 4/5
author: Brian G.

description:
What you need to know:
- a hole in the wall that is a neighborhood joint 
- cash only 
- famous for their dry fried jalapeño chicken wings 
- customer service is a hit or miss 
- this is my go to place in Chinatown for a solid meal
- they offer free soup at beginning of meal (they are old school like that!) 

What we ordered: 
- Fried chicken wings! The skin is wonderfully light and crispy, the flavor is a combo of salt, pepper and a tad spicy and the inside is juicy. What more can you ask! 
- Silky egg and shrimp over thick rice noodles (haw fun) - this is a comfort meal! It's silky, the shrimp has a nice crunch and the noodles are yummy.
author: Karen L.

description:
This is the best Chinese restaurant, just like the ones in Hong Kong! The sweet and sour chicken is  the perfect infusion of sweet and tangy. The beef fried rice is also amazing! It ( the beef fried rice ) has a lot of beef, balancing out the ratio of meat and rice. Both mentioned dishes are recommended. The restaurant was packed! This is a awesome place to go and I really love the food. If you are in the downtown and Chinatown area this is the place to go.
( disclaimer we already ate a lot of the rice so the proportion of the food left was very little)
author: Jennifer L.

description: Chicken wings here are the best hands down! Definitely order before would be best just because it takes around 15 minutes to fry! But overall the food isn't bad and it's cheap too
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Capital has insanely good salt and pepper chicken wings! This is a great location in China Town for some good Chinese food. This is a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant so don't be discouraged to try it out because the food here is very good.

The salt and pepper chicken wings always come out super hot and fresh. The chicken itself is very juicy too! While I'm here we also get the egg foo yung with a choice of your meat. We also got a bowl of soup to share and that's usually enough for us. Anymore and we would over order. I do want to try the other dishes at this restaurant - doesn't seem like you can go wrong here :)
author: Sherry L.

description:
Best salt and pepper wings in the city! If you're looking for an affordable place with good chinese eats this is the place for you! 

It is a whole in the wall kind of shop and most likely you will walk right past this spot if you don't know about it but being asian and having tried a lot of salt and pepper wings... THIS IS THE BEST!!
author: Mel S.

description: I came her for lunch and walked in at 11am, the perfect time before the lunch crowd.  We ordered their famous salt and pepper chicken wings, which came out piping hot, perfectly fried (not greasy) and seasoned.  We also order off the lunch menu - beef and bitter melon with rice and Mongolian beef with rice.  Both dishes were good and for us the perfect size for lunch.  The service was attentive.  I would definitely go back again and again.... happy eating!
author: Lena L.

description: Authentic Chinese Food! We always rely on Yelp to look for amazing restaurants and as usual yelp reviews never fail! However, BRING CASH! No cards are accepted. The service was very prompt and our waitress gave us great suggestions for vegetarian options such as the vegetable chow mein which was delicious! I love the fresh orange slices at the end of your meal :)
author: Lidia D.

description:
Yes, get the salt and pepper wings!! Crispy, delicious and juicy meat. 

Cash only!! 

My friend insisted on the chicken wings so we decided to come here. It is a hole in the wall in Chinatown near Stockton. I came here on a week day for lunch and the place was crowded but had no wait. The service here was good. The servers were friendly and attentive and they gave a free bowl of soup. For two, we ordered the salt and pepper wings and scrambled egg over chow fun (subbed shrimp for beef). They have lunch specials every day. Food is fairly cheap, but not the cheapest. 

I've been to Chinatown for years, but this was my first time stopping by this restaurant. Man, I have been missing out!
author: Christina G.

description: Their salt and pepper chicken wings are the best [salt and pepper] ones I ever had. It usually takes 25-30 minutes for the wings to be ready but when they finally come out, I'm in chicken wings bliss so the wait is worth it. I can eat a whole order myself and have eaten a whole order myself so make sure to order accordingly or guard your wings. The wings go fast especially when eating in family style.
author: Betty L.

description: In this digital world they're still cash only but more than worth the hassle of digging up some dollar bills! The salt and pepper wings are my go to, everything they offer is tasty but their wings are something special, a MUST try when in SF! Nothing commercial about it. (-1star due to cash only)
author: Riona B.

description:
CASH ONLY.

Came by to grab some takeout for their famous chicken wings. I was craving wings for lunch and I remember my coworker told me a while ago that this place was famous for their salt and pepper wings, so I decided to try it out for myself!

I called to place my order around 11:35 on a weekday. By the time I got there 10 min later, it wasn't ready yet, and I had to sit around for another 7-8 minutes until it was ready. So take note to call in takeout orders ~20 minutes beforehand if it's around lunchtime!

As I was waiting for my order, a delivery guy from Grubhub came by to pick up some orders, so apparently their food is available on Grubhub! If I had known that, I might have ordered through there instead of walking all the way to the restaurant and back.

I didn't count how many wings were in each order but there was quite a lot, maybe ~10. The whole thing set me back $10.95 which I thought was a little bit pricey for just wings, but one order was enough to fill me up for lunch so I guess that's not too bad.

I thought the wings were very well done, with just the right amount of flavor and crispiness on the outside and very moist and juicy meat on the inside. My one complaint was that the meat inside was a little bland, so the larger wings with lots of meat were on the blander side. 

Normally the wings come with some jalapenos (at least according to the pictures), so when I placed my order over the phone, I requested they make it not spicy, and they were very accommodating of that.

I'd definitely come back for their wings any time I start craving wings at work again!
author: Dianna H.

description:
EVENT: Sunday stroll in Chinatown and we wanted some fried chicken wings made Chinese style... here we are again... one of our go to Chinese food places!

PARKING: don't even bother with parking... it's a hot mess here! 

SERVICE: your typical Chinese service... in and out we go! We got in hella fast... no wait on a Sunday afternoon... sat on the benches cause there's no tables, but it's totally cool - it's just the Mr. and I. Served tea right away! And took our order right away!

FOOD:
(1) Fried Chicken in salt and pepper, ~$10: Yes, a totally must get! It's pretty steep for just fried chicken wings, but all worth it... we love it here! Crispy and temperature hot... the peppers are a hit or miss (it can sometimes be burning hot.. but most time I can't even taste the hotness!) So... beware! Every bite - you can taste the savory chicken... woots! MSG! Woots! 5 stars

(2) Hot and Sour Soup, $10: one of my all time favorite Chinese food! It's soooo good! One thing... it's pretty pricey for a bowl, but it comes in a bowl! There's lots of "stuff," such as bamboo, chicken, mushrooms, etc... Also, the vinegar is all the way on the bottom... so MIX IT before eating. Or else, when you get to the very bottom... you're gonna just eat vinegar! LOL! Happen to us a couple of times... and we forget! 5 stars!

Price is pretty expensive for Chinese food.. but I guess if it's good... then you'll pay for it.. and I love the chicken and soup here... always coming back! (minus 0.5 stars) 

**MUST GET: Fried Chicken #9 and Hot and Sour Soup (forget what #, LOL) 4.5 stars!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
CHICKEN WINGS: 4
OTHER FOOD: 3.5


I can see why Capital's chicken wings are popular.
First of all, it's $10.50 for 12. Everywhere else in the city, it's the same cost for like, 8. 
These are plump, juicy, and only very lightly battered with a little bit of salt and pepper. I like my wings with more crunch and batter and more flavor, but hey, you can always add salt.

We also got the Fu Kien fried rice. It was decent. Big plus that they didn't make the sauce with hella corn starch.

Overall, the food was just OK for me and all the menu items are standard Cantonese dishes. I see it being a popular tourist spot esp since there's pictures for everything and everything's labeled in English. Price point is fair for the portions as well!

I would recommend this as a quick and easy place for standard, decent Chinese eats.
author: Emily C.

description:
We had family coming down from Canada and Oxnard and it was there first time here visiting the Bay Area. So, we had plan to go up to the city and play tourist for the day. First stop was to have lunch at Chinatown. 
So I relayed on my fellow yelpers and found this restaurant. After reading the review we went with open mind.
We got there around 11. We got seated right away 13 of us. The adults and toddlers were on one big round table and 4 teenagers were seating across us. So, we adults ordered our own and the kids ordered there own.

For starters-

Famous fried chicken - crispy, juicy and flavorful 
2 egg roll -  4 very small pieces cut in half, crispy on the outside but very Mushy inside and no flavor and little bit of filling   

Main entree

Adult table-

Chicken fried rice - worst fired rice ever, it didn't even look like or tasted like 
chicken fried rice.

Clam with black bean sauce - small portions, barely had clam meat in side and it was very very salty. It wasn't good at all. Don't bother getting this dish. Not fresh :(

Chicken chow main - noddle with over done, to soggy , very salty, and chicken was old And rubbery. - even the toddlers didn't like it 

Honey walnut shrimp - it didn't taste like any of the honey walnut shrimp we ever had. It would of been good but it tasted like they put Lemon juice or some kind of ingredient that didn't go well all together. :(

Sweet and sour chicken - now that was just  perfect :) hit the spot,  only good thing there.

BBQ pork egg foo young - meh, no flavor 

Kids ordered 

Chicken fried rice, honey walnut shrimp, orange chicken and I forgot the other order. They didn't like it, especially the orange chicken - it was overly drenched with sweet sauce that it was over powering and it was hard to eat it. So we told our server that our kids didn't like the orange chicken, b'cuz it didn't taste right at all. There were no apology or asked to exchange the food. All we got was a rude response with evil eye saying that's how our orange chicken is. We asked her nicely to take it back and exchange it for the sweet and sour chicken. She replayed by saying that we would still need to pay for the orange chicken b'cuz that's what we ordered. So we're going back and forth with no solutions at all and got the manager. And same thing, no exchange or apology.  All we got was you order, you pay for it. Typical Chinese~ money money money. Don't care about making your customers happy. - It's the principles 

We were embarrassed we've taken our family here to this restaurant. WORST CHINESE FOOD WE EVER EVER EVER HAD IN OUR WHOLE ENTIRE LIFE. $300 down the drain. Don't waste your time and money here. All your gonna get is bad quality food and bad service. We all actually had severe stomach pain from this meal. BEWARE!!
author: Axel M.

description: Been here a few times just to see if I had an isolated bad experience. While it's been"ok" I can't really recommend it. It's always busy but there are other places in Chinatown that are much much better. Service is slow, and the food is just ok. The beef in particular is not enjoyable. Chewy and the taste is not very good.
author: Mike Z.

description: Very yummy.  Friendly service and pretty reasonably priced.  We enjoyed many family different options.
author: Keith R.

description: Great cheap local gem in Chinatown! I always come here for their wings- and used to order them all the time as a kid whenever I'd come with my dad or Uncle. Their other menu items are similar to what you'd get at a Cha chaan teng in HK- definitely a great spot to end the night after boozing at nearby EZ5!
author: James L.

description:
Came here with some friends for lunch. Parking is tough because of Capital's location being on Clay Street in Chinatown. We went here for the chicken wings. Salt and pepper chicken wings with jalapeños, so good!

I'm glad that my friends introduced me to Capitals. I'll be making regular stops here from now on.
author: Philip O.

description:
Love this place. Love the Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings! All of the other Cantonese food is on-point too! It's great that for lunch they also include the soup of the day with your order! This place is really busy during the lunch rush, so be sure to add in extra time if you're on a time limit. Everything is fairly priced and portions are great!

Cash only. Make sure you bring it before you arrive.
author: Nick C.

description:
Went to Capital for lunch with a group of 10. We got a large assortment of food - chicken wings of course, some tofu with spicy pork, fried pork hash, tomato beef curry crispy chow Mein, black bean beef chow fun, green beans with garlic and shrimp egg foo young. Everything was excellent and the entire meal was under $140 for 10 people!  I forgot to order Fukien fried rice!  Next time!  We polished off everything like there
Was no tomorrow.  And the place was packed for lunch!!
author: Donna L.

description: Im giving this place a 5 Star because of their amazing salt and pepper wings. If you are in town please try their wings. FYI CASH ONLY!
author: Julie A.

description: Literally this place has the greatest chicken wings humanly possible. I love their string beans, soup, and again their chicken wings are amazing.  Their service is good and it's a great mom and pop restaurant. They are not always crowded and the workers are quick in their feet. The wait time is short and the restraint is cool. It's been around for a while and to this I still love it. Great place totally recommend it for anyone looking for a good place to eat.
author: Parker M.

description:
Throughout my first 7 years on Yelp I had read a number of reviews about Capital Restaurant and their famous chicken wings often referred to as the best chicken wings in Chinatown, and while I may have meant to bookmark the restaurant I never did.  As time went by I eventually forgot about the restaurant again.

That is until September of 2014 when I finally decided to check out Capital Restaurant after seeing some delicious pics posted by Scottsdale, Arizona Yelp friend Aileen B.  After just that one visit I was sold, and in the past several months I've found myself returning here more often than I have at any other restaurant when visiting San Francisco Chinatown.

Capital's signature Chicken Wings are indeed a big draw here, and I agree they are very good.  I've certainly ordered it on more than three occasions.  These are big, plump chicken wings fried crispy with just the right amount of salt and jalapeno.

My favorite item to order on their vast menu however is the Hung Tao Yee Foo Wonton Soup.  This item was introduced to me by a bail bondsman acquaintance whose office I pass daily on my walk to work.  He's a Capital regular and one night while dining at the counter he stopped by and suggested I try this on my next visit.  I certainly did and I found that I really liked it.  The big plump wontons are deep fried then covered up in a rich seafood-filled broth.  You might think that the process completely negates the deep frying by making the wontons soggy again, but here's the secret.  The wontons end up with a delicious toasted flavor unlike any wonton I've ever had before, and the broth is amazing too combining bits of firm shrimp, squid, scallops and assorted mushrooms.

The Wor Wonton Soup is very good too.  Served in a clearer broth the plump traditional wontons are accompanied by Chinese greens, BBQ pork, mushrooms, shrimp and squid.

If rice is more favorable to your palate I suggest the Fukien Fried Rice.  It's egg fried rice covered in a gravy filled with chicken, shrimp, squid, scallops, Shiitake mushrooms and Chinese broccoli coins.

On par with other Chinese restaurants is the Beef Chow Fun with Bean Sprouts.

One thing I would not recommend is the Fried Crispy Squid which arrived hot and crispy but unseasoned and bland.

The service here is unlike most Chinatown restaurants in that the waitstaff is generally attentive and friendly, two traits not often associated with Chinatown restaurants.  The restaurant is cash only so be sure to come prepared.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: This restaurant used to get five stars.  The food has remained great, but the prices have gone way up and the online menus do not reflect the higher prices.  Wings are listed as $6.75 and they now cost something like $11.  Since it is cash only, you end up paying a lot of $$ out of pocket.  Back in the day, the five stars were well earned for food and value, but now this place is the same as others.  Don't know if I'll be back.
author: Juggy B.

description:
Chinatown history is daunting.  Over the years, it's incredible to fathom how much the neighborhood has changed.  
For old timers, this restaurant used to house one of a handful of Chinese American food spots in Chinatown named Mary's.  These places were widely known by local community residents, business people, and some who worked in the Financial District... Sun Wah Kue, Jackson Café, Tai Sam Yuen, Uncle's, etc.  As these old time favorites slowly closed, Capital came to be a popular breakfast and lunch spot for the local work force.  They offered breakfast favorites like ham or sausage and eggs, omelets, and my favorite ham and macaroni soup.  For lunch, they offered plates with daily specials which include corn beef and cabbage, ox tail stew (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=qeCd6bbxM1T7i7VITWcqDg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  And for the bigger spenders, prime rib is offered.   Is it a culinary experience?  No, merely a chow down reasonably priced eats place.
With the closing of Pacific Court Café, there is a shortage of these businesses in Chinatown other than that roast pork place on Jackson Street.  The nice part here is that you can order Cantonese favorites like chow fun or wonton noodle soup.  
They are famous for their salt and pepper chicken wings, crispy, seasoned perfectly and still juicy inside; do not compare them to those Sunset District dry fried chicken wings as they are just different.
On a recent weekday lunch, not having ordered or eaten here in a while, I picked up an order of Mapo tofu over rice (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SEd4VyCI1DWS3U-a_IzBRQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) which did not disappoint.  They even packed a small container of their house soup to accompany my meal.  
Old time style.  Old time service.  
Sometimes, there's just no reason to change things especially when it's good.
author: Mike C.

description: Very friendly staff. Tasty food.  Not fancy.  Chicken wings is a must get. You will easily overlook this place but if you have a few days in sf it's worth a visit.  Not really a must go type place but a comfortable tasty spot
author: John C.

description: My relatives and I mostly come to this restaurant for birthdays or holidays. Today, I came to this place for some chicken wings because my aunt always says they have the best ones. I ordered to eat in and the chicken wings were done in 10 minutes. The chicken wings are so crispy and delicious. You can just feel the sizzling taste in your tongue. It was just so good!! I will definitely be back!
author: Jonathan Z.

description: (From close to closing experience)Pretty good all around small Chinese restaurant. The servers were well friendly but can understand that they just wanna do their job and feed you. In the place of Chinatown I feel it was a basic place to grab food. They DO NOT accept any kind of card payment, ONLY CASH. But the food was delicious and might come back in the near future. Very Clean to add.
author: Johnny S.

description: Average over-all. Went for the basic Chinese-American fare. Mongolian beef chow mein was moderately spicy but did not have that underpinning of ginger. Meh. Orange chicken had an almost maple syrup flavor to it with barely a hint of citrus after taste. Was not finished. Singapore rice noodles good. Chicken wings for appetizer was best part of meal. Make sure you bring cash.
author: James P.

description:
This place seems like a popular place for regulars to meet up for lunch.  

Been here a few times & the food takes a long time to come.  Expect to wait at least 30 minutes and if it's crowded - you may feel like walking out!  

The food is good - not great & not worth waiting 30-40 minutes.  I do like that the cook does not overly season their food.  Some veggies were over cooked or par-boiled.   Love their chow mean/fun dishes.
Chicken wings were just okay.  

Wait staff are great & very friendly.  That is a big plus in Chinatown!!

I will go back as there are few Decent places to eat in Chinatown these days.
author: Marie E.

description:
Definitely a hole in the wall chinese restaurant, but most of the ones in Chinatown are. 

I ordered the bittermelon with chicken to go. Bittermelon is an acquired taste so I dont recommend it unless you like bitter food. 

They seem to be known for their fried chicken wings here. I may have to come back and order that to go next time. 

Cash only!
author: Claire W.

description:
Yum!! Chinese restaurants are always more fun when you come with a big group, so you can try all the different dishes! Coming here, I knew the two must-tries were the salt & pepper fried wings and the egg tofu - they didn't disappoint! 

Salt & pepper fried wings - OoOoOo! The batter is really crispy and they were definitely reallyyyyyy salty (actually I didn't even taste any pepper/spice)!! Try to take bites of the crispy batter WITH the bland meat so that you won't be having unbelievable bites of what seems like a shot of salt! Meat was juicy and tender so it being paired with the salty crisp batter was delicious!

Egg tofu - LOVE!! This was my favorite dish! I tried the non-spicy version because not everyone in the group liked spicy, but I can't wait to come back and try the spicy version!! The egg tofu was incredibly soft and silky and came with a delicious fu-kien gravy-like sauce of shrimp, mushrooms, Chinese broccoli and meat. 

Ong choi - Cooked wonderfully with garlic.. can't go wrong with this one!

Chow mein / Fried rice - Portion were small for both of them. These two dishes lacked flavor... if you can tell from my picture, the rice in the fried rice was almost white!!! Did they forget soy sauce..?! Oyster sauce?? Seeing a white fried rice is an embarrassment to all fried rices!! Haha.. bottom line, skip on these! (I'm interested in their fu-kien fried rice though!) 

I look forward to coming back and trying out their other dishes.
author: Kris C.

description:
Solid lunch, and the perfectly done salt/pepper wings ( more the former, hardly present the latter) were cooked to a nice crispness.

Large portions, sat at counter. Quickish turnaround time. $8-9 lunch specials, cash only.
author: Jana C.

description: This place is killing it! The food is great and the salt and pepper wings are the best. I don't really eat fried food at all and this is most definitely an exception to my whole not liking fried food. It's a cash only hole in the wall and is well worth the wait whether it's the line or looking for parking
author: Drew K.

description:
Big fan of the SALT & PEPPER WINGS. Wings are pretty big and good quality too. For $10.50 you get 12 wings, which is a good deal considering most places give you 8-10 for that price. If you're a wing connoisseur, this place has to be on your list to try.

We tried the FUKIEN FRIED RICE (seafood fried rice, I would order that again), BEEF CHOW FUN (not very flavorful) and the HOT & SOUR SOUP (lacked flavor too). 

Service and venue isn't anything to write about, but you kind of forgive all shortcomings once you bite into a salt & pepper wing. 

The 4 star rating is because I am a big fan of the wings. I can't say much for the other items on the menu (I heard there's a ribeye special on Tuesdays? and the Shanghai Style noodles looked good). 

I will be back. Once a week. Maybe more.
author: Patrick M.

description: The best Chinese food restaurant, period. The food at Capital Restaurant is absolutely amazing! It's unlike any Chinese restaurant I've tried before. (And believe me- I've tried A LOT). I think the best part about it was the food here wasn't heavy. They didn't use tons of heavy sauces. It was very light & very tasty. It had you coming back for more and more and more and more! Truly the best Chinese food I could ever recommend. Will be coming here on all my San Fran trips from now on!!
author: Isabella H.

description: We had the special wings salt and pepper w jalapeño. It was really good. Just stopped in for a snack so didn't have any of the entire dishes. I will say they all looked good however we passed as other tellers have given mixed reviews (outside of the wings).
author: Matthew K.

description:
In the '60s and '70s, most Bay Area towns had at least one greasy spoon that served Chinese and American food.  Ping Yuen Bakery and Cafe on Pacific served a three course meal for a bargain price. I remember talking to an owner there who bragged that they bought their prime rib and steak from the same supplier as the Fairmont Hotel because a co-owner was a chef at the Fairmont.  The prime rib and French lamb chops were good there.  The other two courses were not very good, but it was a bargain.  

Capital seems like the last of this dying breed.  I have walked by this place many times, but never entered until now.  

Mom said the place is a favorite of ABCs (American Born Chinese). Funny, she was born in SF, but never took me here until Friday.  The fried chicken wings are its most notable dish and the prime rib special served only on Tuesday is in the same vein as Ping Yuen's.  I asked if there was a special of the day and the waitress looked at me like I was crazy.

We started with the fried chicken wings which were beautifully fried.  The skin was very salty and crunchy.  Too bad the chicken meat was lacking flavor.  I was very disappointed.  I think they should marinate or brine the wings before frying.

We also had West Lake soup, black bean clams, garlic sautéed snowpea greens and white rice.  What can I say...the greens were good.

The place was really noisy and all of the customers were speaking English, except for a group of French tourists.  When we left, someone was smoking a cigarette in the restaurant.  We could not see who it was but the smell was very strong.  I think it came from a table of restaurant employees who were eating their dinner.

I think nostalgia led me to expect a better meal.  Even in the old days these Chinese American food places were sub-par, so why would it be great 40 years later?
author: Joanna S.

description:
Everyone comes here and raves about the super crispy salt and pepper chicken wings.. those are good but honestly not great. Better wings at other places for a lower price too (though they do give you a CRAP ton of wings). Seriously, there's a platter full of them. 

So you might be wondering why I'm writing a 5 star review for average chicken? Well I'm not, this 5 stars is for my sweet baby angel, the fried wonton seafood soup! Get it, love it, cherish it, make a house and home for it because it's actually that good. Ask them to bring the wontons on the side so they stay crispy. OMG, writing this makes me want to go there and tear up an order of it right now. Hallelujah, praise god. Get it and thank me later.
author: Krystal B.

description: Decent Cantonese Chinese food. Nothing special. Good salt and pepper wings. Pretty cheap prices too.
author: Peter K.

description:
The legendary salt and pepper chicken wings lured me out to explore Chinatown beyond my usual dim sum spot. 

I got there a little before they opened at 11 and was encouraged by the fact that a little Chinese grandma was already waiting patiently outside the door. Wow, I thought, this place MUST be good.

Ten minutes and a brisk walk around later, I let myself in and sat down at the counter to order wings to go. Cash only. Oddly, the early bird grandma was sitting in the waiting area and seemed content there the entire time, even as other patrons came and went.

As I waited for my order, I was charmed by the fact that regulars dropped in for their usual orders and exchanged pleasantries. It was a new, laid back and real side of Chinatown I'd never seen as a tourist before on the more crowded streets.

And dang, those wings were crispy perfection! The SO gave a thumbs up too. Even if we don't have time to eat in, we'll be back for more takeout wings in the future.
author: Sue V.

description:
Found this place on SF Eater's latest list - http://sf.eater.com/maps/where-eat-drink-restaurants-bars-chinatown-san-francisco

Mellow Chinatown restaurant that's part typical chinese restaurant with large round tables & lazy susans and part diner with a long low bar to sit and eat near the entrance. Lots of formica type coverings.

Seems to be mostly filled with regulars and the occasional tourist who seems surprised to find themselves here.

We ordered everyone's favorite 3 dishes - 

- chicken wings: came out last, hot/salty/peppery with perfect crisp skin and bland meat (bland meat was expected from the reviews), not sure it was worth it just for the skins yummy though they were

- fried egg tofu with spicy meat sauce: soft pillow tofu deep fried (?) in large pieces and served with a ground meat & bell pepper sauce, interesting but the sauce was kinda standard

- empress clam: sliced clam with vermicelli noodles, I didn't see on the menu so asked for it and they knew immediately what I was talking about, yes it comes with two servings but they're small so if you're with someone who doesn't like seafood just eat them both yourself and lay off the chicken wings

I liked the food but will probably go try a few other places before deciding if/when I'll return. Note: I've been on a tear with Fuchsia Dunlop's cookbooks at home so as my Chinese home-cooking game increases my satisfaction with Chinese restaurants goes down. But you are not me so take it all with a grain of salt.

3 dishes plus 2 rice (1 too many) = $40 including tax & tip, enough for 3 meals
author: Jean K.

description: Food was really good and their Garlic Chicken Wings lived up to name...the best I've ever had.  We had chicken, pork and veggie dishes and they were all outstanding.  Coming back next time I'm in S.F.
author: Milton S.

description:
About a month ago I had the pleasure of visiting this restaurant with a few friends on vacation. 
We had another restaurant in mind, but on a whim we decided to try this place because it smelled delicious and we were starving. 
I ordered the specialty chicken wings, the chicken fried rice (not my idea, way too basic), and the honey walnut shrimp. 
Hunty.....let me tell you-the chicken wings were bomb. After the first bite I started calling them wangz because they were deserving of their own name. 

The honey walnut shrimp was on point too, however the chicken fried rice was lacking. Normally, I wouldn't have ordered that but it was a Sunday and I was trying to turn over a new leaf by humbling myself and not taking over my friends order. Lesson learned. 

The next time I return will try one of the barbeque pork rices, because they sounded and looked tasty on the restaurant menu picture. No complaints though, everything was fresh and tasted fantastic! Looking forward to my next visit!
author: Ariel T.

description: The salt and pepper chicken wings is the best! And, it's so crispy! I really recommend it.
author: Winnie H.

description: The Honey Walnut Shrimps is one of their best dishes. We asked for a Wonton Soup and not really sure if I'd order it again. Their House Special Chow Mein is very delicious.
author: Carlos R.

description:
Capital's salt and pepper chicken wings have consistently been Chinatown's most popular wings for the past 15 years that I've known about them. Ask anyone familiar with the area and they'll nod their head in complete agreement, but Capital often flys under the radar due to their location.

The salt and pepper chicken wings are burn-your-hands hot, crispy and golden, super juicy, and sprinkled with the perfect amount of salt. Simple, but well-executed, and affordable at that. 

Delicious in house or to-go, you'll see every patron with a plate of wings on their table, or locals shuffling in and out to pick up orders to enjoy at home. Don't pay much attention to the no-nonsense service and plain decor...it shouldn't be a problem though cuz your meal will have your full attention!
author: Deanna Y.

description: The chicken wings were hyped for a reason...they are really that good.  Fresh out from the kitchen, extremely hot, you'll need to wait a moment.
author: Brian B.

description: Ehhh, don't mind me. Just making a note to myself to try somewhere else next time I'm in China town. There's a decent priced dinner special, skinny lo mein noodles, over sauced sour pork, beef fried rice was good.... CASH ONLY so prepare for some ATM fees.  Food comes out pretty fast..... so I guess if you're in a hurry. It's not that this place is bad, it's just that I've had better.
author: Kayla S.

description:
Ahh.. my FIRST REAL REVIEW for 2015 !

Located in the heart of Chinatown it was a bit hard for me to find since I am not from San Francisco but when I did get nearby I recognized the sign from afar!

The place is a bit cramped but hey it is Chinatown. The owner greeted us and was extremely helpful! We ordered the crab, clams and their famous wings.

Crab: It was OK. I couldn't say it was amazing but it wasn't awful. It could use more garlic , green onion and salt.

Wings: They were perfectly salted on the outside but inside it was just really bland.

Clams: MY FAVORITE DISH! The noodles were fragrant with the "wok hei" and the clams were stir fry in garlic. UGH. DELISH!!

Overall my experience was good! I might not be back only because there is so many places to try in Chinatown so it might be a little while until I return.

Thank you Capital Restaurant for being so kind and helpful!
author: Nancy D.

description: The chicken wings live up to their name - crispy outside, juicy inside. The only thing that would make them better? Spicy. Bonus: I had them delivered once...and they arrived piping hot!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Chicken wings were yummy. Clay pot was decent as well. I got a stomachache half-way through and I'm not sure if it was because of this restaurant or something I ate earlier. Either way, it was still really good.

Might I venture to say that I like these wings more than San Tung's? (dodges one million flying tomatoes) I like my wings dry and not wet I guess.
author: Ber B.

description:
Went to try this place out Sunday night since my friend was given a flyer of it. Well it looked good in pictures. There was a wait to be seated. We waited maybe about five min for five of us. When we got inside it was SOOO hot! 

We order a total of seven dishes. We actually got six to begin with, but it wasn't enough for the five of us. The portion sizes are meant to be for two to three people to share. Between the five of us we seriously only got two to three pieces of each dish. 

We order: Chicken Cream Corn Soup, The Famous Chicken Wings, Vinegar Sauce Spareribs, Orange Chicken, Honey Walnut Prawns, Chinese Broccoli with garlic and white rice. 

I thought there was too much salt on the wings. The soup was good. The ribs weren't bad. The orang chicken was eh, I had better. The honey walnut prawns weren't prawns, but was good. Chinese broccoli was good and the white rice was good too.

I checked in and unlocked the "lemonade drink" since you get that free for checking in. We'll...I put it in quotes cause all it is is some lemon juice, water, and a couple pieces of lemon. I couldn't believe it. And it's regular price is $2.95! Seriously!? It was gross. I took one sip and passed. 

Also getting to the service. Our server wasn't the nicest or friendly-est person there. I asked about that lemonade drink when we got there and she totally forgot about it, I had to ask another lady for it. Then we had to ask for water refills and when we asked they seem like they weren't too happy about that. Then since they wrote in Chinese on our check we can't read it, we aren't chinese so my friend asks the lady what it says and he goes "sorry we can't read this..." And she says back to him "YEAH, I know." Wow!!! Excuse us.

So overall, I WON'T Be back! My friends and I didn't see what was so great about this place. I don't see how this place has three and a half stars, guess mine and my friends taste buds are just not into this. Oh and they ONLY take CASH!!
author: Akemi H.

description:
Much time has passed since I first strode off to sup at Capital Restaurant only to find that it was temporarily closed for refurbishment. That long-ago ambition was fed by my desire to try their salt and pepper chicken wings.

Today I was richly rewarded with wonderful chicken wings served hot and accompanied by slices of green peppers that kicked it all up a notch.

And what splendid surprise did green beans with minced pork and red pepper flakes provide this willing pilgrim.

The wait staff were pleasant and I adore the old-school diner decor complete with counter service just to the left as you walk through front door.

I will return. Oh, I will return.
author: Jay D.

description: I ordered the fried chicken wings and a side of steam rice to go. Sorry but I found the wings bland. I can taste the msg on the skin but the meat itself is bland.  Plus some of the wings are small.
author: roderick s.

description:
Although their chicken wings is good but if only see how they clean n cook their food. 
I was discussing when I went to restroom n saw how they prepare their wings.
Will not eat their again.

Owner are not friendly and tables of 4 are cut the width short that 2 people can't fit. U will be sitting half way out.

Shame be going there over 20 years.

Only focus on tourism which know they will not return.
author: Peter L.

description:
Heard the craze on these chicken wings so i had to come try it. 
Called in advance to order 2 sets of chicken wings to go.
Got there in 30 minutes because of SF crazy traffic.
Came out to be around $11 per box of wings.
Ranged around 10 wings or little more per box.
Flavor was flavorful so itd be better if one eats it with rice. 
Tasted like chinatown classic salt n pepper wings but i assume the other high ratings is for their consistency.
Can probably eat 20-30 wings in a setting cuz im a wing lover.
Wouldnt drive to Chinatown just for the wings though because chinatown be crazy in terms of transportation. 
Recommended for all wing lovers.
author: Auden W.

description:
Found this restaurant on YELP - a good catch.        They have very fresh and delicious lunch specials.  Great classic (American style) Chinese food as well as traditional local Chinese.     
Prices are very reasonable for large delicious portions.     I had the hot & sour soup (small is plenty for one) which was great.     And the shrimp with vegetables and rice, very fresh and good.      My gf had the grilled pork and string beans and she loved it.    
We sat at a communal table and set cue was fast.      Here's a photo.   
A good find amongst a SEA of restaurants in Chinatown.
author: chris b.

description: Holy fuck in a library. This place absolutely sucked giant hairy flaming baboon dick. Like....Jesus fucking electrocute my nipples with a military issued rusty taser Christ this place is horrendous. How do u fuck up fried chicken wings this bad????????????????? It was dry, bland, and still full of msg. All u literally have to do us put chicken wings in the fryer for like 5 minutes and they still managed to fuck that up. How in the world do u make fried chicken wings taste like godamn boiled chicken breast bra????
author: Edward H.

description: Overatted chicken wing. It was too salty, but they did fried it perfectly, gotta admit that. Juicy inside crispy outside, but overall is too salty. Fukken fried rice was salty as well. You will find urself drinking a lot of tea after. I would not consider cheap just because it located in Chinatown plus you can find better food that was served under their price point. Service was meh, but it's normal because that's the signature of any chinatown in the US. Really? people would go here to eat from Canada or LA, no..not sure if these tourist just happened to pass by and owner makes it that up. I doubt it because it 's really normal food, nothing special. The FB video will help to draw the crowd in, but think twice if you wanted to fly all the way here for so so food. My opinion above is based on all the good food I tried so far in CA. If you wanna go beyond what we call high quality food, please visit China. I would not recommend this place, but if u happen to pass by, why not right?
author: Elsa Mandy G.

description: The Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings are insanely good.  The flavor is amazing and the skin is super crispy.  This is a must stop for us when in town.  Located in SF Chinatown so parking can be tricky.  The place is small... filled with mostly locals.  Cash only so stop by a ATM before hand... took us awhile to find one near.
author: Paty G.

description:
I only go here for the VERY ADDICTING chicken wings which i believe they are the best chicken wings I've ever had. Much better than San Tung chicken wings, but I like the dried style over the wet sauce-y kind. 

The other food is okay - not bad but not great.
author: Cicely T.

description:
CASH ONLY.  2nd time to Capital Restaurant for dinner Sat 11/22/14.  We beat the crowd by going there around 5:30pm.

Got:

FREE hot tea - fine
FREE lemonade - with Yelp Check-In.  Tasted ok, sweet and tangy.  I think there was a dead bug in it noticed it way too late, so then I couldn't finish it.  Bleh.
B. got a beer - he drank it all
Big pea shoots w/ garlic - tasty, favorite dish.
Beef clay pot - not much meat, lots of tendons, and dried bean curd.  I liked the brown sauce.
I think it was Fried oysters w/ onions - B. liked it, I didn't eat it.
Huge pot of white rice

CASH ONLY.  We paid $44.95 before tip.

Bathroom through the kitchen - I didn't want to use it.
author: Ann L.

description: Not impressed with this old-school Chinese place. Got the shrimp with fresh mushrooms lunch special and it was literally 7 baby shrimp, some boring veggies and a huge mound of rice. It was also flavorless. Maybe the chicken wings are worth coming for...
author: Geoffrey U.

description: Had lunch (if that's what you want to call it) at the Capital Restaurant. Having to fight for the attention of the employees should have tipped us off that this was going to be an awful experience, but we are positive thinkers. We had asked for a split check, and apparently this was too complex of a task because the splitting of the check was the catalyst for an avalanche of overwhelmingly disappointing behavior that lead to me, someone who never left a yelp review, to waste time out of my trip to San Francisco to write this review to warn any human being (or animal that might want to eat the trash from this place) to stay away from here. Not only was the food worse than freshly mowed grass, the waitress fumbled up our split check, overcharging us for the plastic food. It took 30 minutes to sort out the mess because of the waitress' incompetence and almost malicious behavior, and the only reason why it ended was because we decided this whole exchange wasn't worth it anymore. Honest to god, avoid this hellhole of a restaurant. It is a void of happiness and anything positive in this world.
author: Jeffrey G.

description:
Chicken wings!! Get the chicken wings!! Every table in the restaurant orders the chicken wings! Even the waitresses there will assume you'll order the chicken wings! 

$9.85 for 12 chicken wings!

Order the Egg Tofu w/ Spicy Minced Meat and the dried scallops egg white fried rice!

And also remember to get a free lemonade with Yelp Check-In and you'll be set to have a tasty meal!

The waitresses are super nice too!
author: Alice X.

description: Enjoyed very much the Cantonese homestyle entrees here.  Prices are cheap.  Restaurant is a bit small & cozy-tight.  Very busy!  Staff works hard to accommodate all diners & are nice.  Cash only.  Staff speaks Cantonese, Mandarin, & English.
author: Diana L.

description:
Chicken Wings are my weakness. Especially when they're fresh out of the fryer. Oh man...I think I'm related to Paula Deen somehow. 

I found out about Capital's Fried Chicken Wings after seeing them on so many blogs. People claim that these are one of the best chicken wings they ever had. And to be honest...now I know why.

They serve you around 10 pieces for $7.95. Surprisingly, the pieces are pretty big in size. But bottom line...I love how crispy they are! Literally like biting into a bag of potato chips. And I like the green onions and jalapenos that come along with every plate. So addicting! 

Service is kinda slow. Took a good 20 mins for my food to arrive. But hey at least they serve good food! I tried their soup bowls too. Comforting for the cold night but nothing too special. If you come here...order the wings!!!!!!
author: Ralph N.

description:
Surprisingly great Chinese food place in Chinatown

Chinese food is everywhere in Chinatown, and whenever I walked by this place I had always avoided it because the decor seemed sub-par. This all changed when I went in for the first time--the food quality is really awesome! The fried tofu I had was perfectly cooked, with a crispy exterior and a tofu interior that is semi-solid--enough to hold itself together when you pick it up with chopsticks, but soft enough to crumble when you bite into it. The spiciness is also just right. The food quality of the place is especially surprising, given that this little modest shop one of the better restaurants I've eaten at in c-town. Talk about exceeding expectations!

The washroom is the one thing that is non-ideal (you have to walk in the kitchen, and past the entire kitchen crew), but the folks who work there seem to be doing the best they can with what they have (trying to keep it clean, by c-town standards). A lot of other c-town restaurants degrade to unimaginable levels (I'm looking at you, Sam Woo), which just goes to show how much effort the Capital Restaurant folks put into running the place with the sub-par equipment they were given.

Plus, you can get free lemonade for a Yelp check-in. That almost never happens in c-town! w00t

Keep up the good work!
author: Henry L.

description: Delicious, salty, crispy jalapeño chicken wings. Service is amazing and the owner is a super sweet lady. Chinatown is full of hidden gems like this place!
author: J.J. P.

description:
Cash only!!!

Specifically came for the salt and pepper chicken wings... 

THAT IS ALL!!!

We ordered other items, but didn't compare.

S&P WINGS!!!
author: Maria C.

description:
This review is solely for their Chicken Wings. 

The wings are by far the best wings in the area. It always comes out hot and it is extremely tasty and crunchy. The wings are dry not wet. Everyone that I have recommended the chicken wings to have always given me positive feedback!

Cash Only, BTW!
author: Bianca C.

description: The food was tasty. The service was... authentic.The portions were quite large; 2 dishes could easily feed 4 or 5 people.
author: Benjamin C.

description: my friend suggested i go here for the "world famous" chicken wings. i came in with such high expectations and was very let down with the wings. one thing they have down is a very light batter that stays very crispy for a very long time. other than that the chicken is pretty bland even though they put salt and msg on it. there are plenty of other chinese restaurants that have way better tasting wing than capital but none of the use the term "world famous". i guess term is used to bait tourist who dont know any better.
author: Art N.

description:
Came here with two friends last night, on the recommendation of Veasna H to try their chicken wings. The three of us ended up getting their:

* Chicken Wings - Unlike other wings in the city, these are of the dry fried, unsauced variety, seasoned primarily with salt and peppers. Tasty, albeit a bit dry from being fried too long.

* Egg Tofu w/ Special Meat Sauce - Not entirely sure why this was under the vegetarian section, but, basically, lightly fried egg-covered silken tofu discs, topped with meat sauce. Not bad, but a bit on the bland side, and not as spicy as the waitress hinted at.

* Oxtail Clay Pot - First off, this was served in a metal bowl, not a clay pot. Secondly, the meat was surprisingly fatty. Aside from that though, this dish was pretty tasty.

All in all, about what one would expect of Chinese food, in a fairly clean and spacious restaurant. Service was also much better than you normally find in this part of town. Cash only, so come prepared.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A medium sized restaurant that opens up towards the back, but is a little more narrow up front due to the counter seating. When full, people will likely have to scoot or get out of their seats for you to pass.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description: Great menu selections. Flavors varied. Steamed clam dish was bland and didn't taste like chewy clams, more like mealy fish. Decent fried chicken. Great tofu, mushroom dish.  Oxtail stew was decent; unusual flavors but edible. Medium MSG level; contact lens haven't curled up yet but very dry mouth and eyes.
author: L T.

description:
No! Don't come here. I'm confused on the reviews and why this places was crowded when we showed up for a bite. Is it a tourist trap? Was it because Chinese New Year weekend was happening in Chinatown? 

My husband and i were told before heading out to San Francisco we would have some of the best Chinese food in America . I took out my mighty yelp app and let the force guide my way. The darkness fell over yelp that day as we walked into Capital Restaurant. 

We were ushered to a two person table top and given menus near the door.  The table and chairs were very retro by that I mean they were probably here when the place first opened. The menu had a huge selection to choose from. The outside and the inside of the building had pictures of the food so it could help in making an easier decision.

After waiting about 10 minutes after putting in our drink order of water and tea I was getting frustrated. There seemed to be only one waitress for the whole place! WTF?!!? We finally put our food orders in and the wait began. This place is fairly cheap food and shouldn't take forever to cook. 

I ordered the fried tofu seafood hot pot. The fried tofu was soggy (even the pieces not in the broth). The seafood was good  but overall this lacked flavor. My husband meal is where it went downhill in a bad way. He ordered what I called the "tourist trap combo meal". It contained: soup, sweet and sour chicken, white rice, egg roll, and fortune cookie. The soup he decided to get was wonton and it was very Delicious and then the rest of the meal came out. I swear LaChoy family meal in a can taste better than what was served. The beef and broccoli was similar to some MRE meal I had eaten out of desperate while I served time in the Middle East while in the Army. The egg roll was overcooked and burnt. Also it didn't look like your traditional egg roll as it wasn't deep fried.

If this wasn't bad enough after the meals we didn't finish our meals. :( We decided 
  we both wanted to use the restroom before heading out back into Chinatown. I went first in search of the restroom to be told it was located in the kitchen area. WTF?!? I went thur the kitchen to discover the cooks preparing food and see a makeshift bathroom/cleaning closet that serves as a unisex bathroom. I came back and told my husband where to go. Apparently he went farther down into the kitchen and ended up seeing 2-3 sinks full of meat with water pouring of it. I assume for defrosting??

Side note: I am alive and well today
author: Amanda K.

description:
Simple, clean Chinese food in Chinatown.  What more are you looking for? 

Everything we had was cooked and seasoned just right, without being too oily. I love a place where I can get fried rice that is white, not yellow or brown. Light and fresh.  

Recommend: 

1. The Pea shoots with garlic. They actually put fresh garlic buds in the dish!
2.  Garlic chicken. Fried perfectly in a sweet and spicy sauce.

Every waitress was nice, and some of them were quite funny. It was a nice balance of good service and that industrious pace you expect in authentic Chinese restaurants.

Finally, reasonably priced. Three of us had two dishes each, and the total bill was under $60.   

Only thing lacking, as you can probably guess, is ambience. But I refuse to take away a star. Chinese restaurants in Chinatown cannot be evaluated on their ambience.

Definitely plan to return...
author: Brian F.

description:
I love this restaurant !! Don't know why I haven't done a review for this place..?? Use to come here with my Dad for lunch.. He been coming here n lunch for passed 20 years..
My favorite dish is the salt n pepper fried chicken wings.. A must must order..
Mince meat over tofu omg another must order..!!
And don't forget there are daily lunch specials which is fast n great value..!!! Comes with soup n dessert..!!!
author: Crisy G.

description: Most favorite place in Chinatown!  So "satisfied" every time finish lunch or dinner here!  No need to talk about chicken wings coz The Most favorite dish here.  95% of customers order this dish!  And yes, you must must try!  Our next favorite is Fukien style egg tofu 福建玉子豆腐！Don't think any other place makes tofu better than this.  I brought many of my friends from Hong Kong to Capital and they all amazed we have such good Chinese restaurant in US!
author: Cindy H.

description:
Review is for the wings, because why would you get anything else here? Jk, I had the regular food here and it was alright.
Back to the wings: 12 (yes, I counted them) juicy, hot, crispy, slightly spicy wing thingies for ~$9. Sure, their prices went up, but it's still worth it. The wings are amply sized. 
Only complaint: the msg they sprinkle on the wings.
author: Karen C.

description:
I've been coming here for so long. There's so many items on their menu and I've had my fair share of a lot of them. I don't think there's a dish that I haven't liked. They give great portions so it's great for family style dining. Every time I come here I have to get their SALT AND PEPPER CHICKEN WINGS. They're so bomb and with so much flavor and the crisp is perfect. They also have sauced wings, but I like the classic wings. 

The place itself is pretty small, but I don't think I've ever had to wait too long to be seated. I've been coming here for so long that they recognize me and they've seen me grow up haha. Great service and I can't ever say anything bad about this place.
author: Kelly T.

description:
This was one of the best meals I had on my visit to SF. We picked this among the other in Chinatown because one review remarked on the quality of the chicken wings. That reviewer was absolutely correct; they were amazingly crispy, moist, and the flavor was perfect. I think everyone in our group was pleased with their meals but we all favored the Orange Chicken order by my friend. Great service too.

I think it's important to note when we arrived, the entire staff was sitting at a table eating their lunch. They politely asked if we were okay with waiting 10-15 minutes to be served. Our group was more than happy to oblige. Myself being in the service industry, giving your staff an actual sit-down lunch break to eat is a great concept.
author: Jessica G.

description:
The hyped Salt/Pepper Chicken Wings were A-OK, but far from the best. The outside skin is fried well and has a hint of salt, but the inside is flavorless.

When I asked for the Prime Rib lunch special, they said there were sold out. Nearing the end of the meal, two grandpas got the prime rib lunch that was "sold out" 20 minutes earlier?!?

I got the beef stew noodle soup, good portion, but the soup was bland.

The other 3 lunch special rice places were decent but nothing stood out.

$50 for 4 during lunch...only in a pinch.
author: Peter L.

description: Love their salt and pepper wings!!! Constantly crave it. I haven't experienced a wait here yet. A lot of people get their wings to-go. It comes out pretty fast too, probably because they have it prepared since like every table orders it. It comes out really hot and fresh too! We also ordered the salty fish fried rice and that was pretty good too! Great portions and great prices! Really good customer service for Chinatown too! Very attentive and friendly. Definitely recommend!
author: Bailey L.

description:
The chicken wings here are exceedingly superior to the ever-popular San Tung variety. Yeah, I said it. While San Tung douses their chicken in sticky, cloyingly sweet sauce, Capital preserves the integrity of the wings with simple, balanced flavors that just work. The exterior of each chicken wing is perfectly crispy and salty, with a hint of jalapeño spice, and the meat inside remains tender and juicy and sooooo gooooood. The egg tofu is also worth noting, and serves as a nice side dish.

I will say that the restaurant may not be too aesthetically inviting, but don't let that deter you. True beauty lies deep within. I've always had a wonderful experience dining here. Capital's is one of the few Chinese restaurants I feel comfortable going to without bringing along someone who speaks Chinese. The waitstaff is always pleasant and efficient, and the wait time for food is never unreasonable. Capital's, I Love you (with a CAPITAL "L" heh heh heh, get it... because the name of their restaurant is "Capital" heh heh heh... I'll see myself out).
author: Kristen C.

description: Classic Chinese restaurant with large portions. Delicious tomato beef, reminds me of my childhood.
author: Albert Y.

description:
Being unable to get a seat at another place, I came across Capital and had a meal there.  The place is kind of chaotic; the service was disjointed but OK.  But the food was really poor.  

A starter of honey roasted pork was fatty and greasy.  The pork was very thinly sliced and for the price was a meager portion.  So this course was l loser in every way.

Mongolian beef was tasteless and sitting in a large puddle of oil.   Terrible.

Enough said.
author: David D.

description: We were referred to this restaurant by an SF resident "in the know" when it comes to good eats, and boy was she right about Capital Restaurant, seriously the best Chinese Food anybody in my family has ever eaten!! We had the sizzling rice seafood soup, pork chow mein, spare ribs and the FRIED CHICKEN WINGS. Absolutely everything was perfection & my husband, whose traveled extensively in China, says that the ambiance is spot on authentic!
author: Kendra L.

description:
It's all about the Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings!

Finally, a dish that lives up to its hype! I got the wangs and a side of rice, and WOW. They must've laced it with crack (just kidding, it's probably MSG) because it's so addictingly good! The dish comes with japaleno slices. It's deep fried to perfection, so it's crispy on the outside and juicy and moist on the inside. There's flavor on the outside (salt and pepper) and flavor on the inside (chicken juices). YUM.

One portion ($10) will feed two semi-hungry people or one starving person. Apparently the famous Will Smith came here and proclaimed that it's the best wings in the western hemisphere. I agree 100%.
author: Nari C.

description:
egggg tofuuu forr dayyyyzz! that dish is soo soo goood!

tried capital restaurant last night based on a gf's recommendation, and was pleased! we ordered - the wings (obvi), egg tofu (SO YUMM), roasted duck, west lake beef soup, and curry beef clay pot. they give you a bunch o' rice to wash everything down with. i thought the duck was really well done! warm and just fatty enough, and the juices were good for flavor. clay pot and soup were a bit bland, but it is cantonese food! expect it to be a bit bland! hahah :) 

$27 per person for the above, and we got beers. not a bad deal, since we had leftovers... place was packed with a variety of customers. the service was all right - it's a chinese restaurant, not gary danko :P
author: Christina L.

description:
While I was reading through some of the comments here, I read a lot of positive reviews with four stars. Well.... I have to give this one a FIVE! I can be a little bias though because I do love chicken wings, but still, I am pretty positive that many of you will too! 

Nothing really stood out when I walked in. Pretty normal China Town Restaurant with normal looking people. Normal here, normal there, bluh bluh bluh, average here, average there.. And then, I took a bite of their Chicken wings and I swear the average things around me became....... MAJESTIC! Each bite, I was scrutinizing every flavor that was touching my tongue and activating my nerve cells! Each bite I felt like I was flying in the sky. EACH BITE made me even more excited for the next! Even the word succulent was derived from these Chicken Wings!  Okay.. some of this doesn't make sense.. but a chicken wing like this... even a poet would not be able to put it into words. LOL
author: John L.

description:
Been here many times and took so many people here in the past. Every single time I'd always the order the chicken wings, which now has became their signature dish. It always comes out piping hot. What's great is that ALL the wings are same size, and the good number of them. The outer layer (skin) of the chicken is fried to perfection.  Sprinkles of salt makes the wings tasty. BUT...there's a big BUT...it's just the outside that's good. Right when you tear off the crispy skin, the chicken meat is quite bland. It's hard to resist when you see everyone orders it!

Besides the chicken, my most ordered dish is the stir fry noodles with chinese broccoli and shrimp. Here, you can always custom your noodles or chow fun. Just today, I heard a customer told the waiter she wanted noodles and chow fun and asked the kitchen to whip up something. The waitress are very experienced, been there forever. They are friendly and attentive. 

What's unique about this place is that you'll find a nice piece of steak and a plate of chow fun on the same menu. The interior might look run down, but the restaurant is well lit and may be one of the cleaner restaurant in Chinatown. 

Cash only. Free soup!
author: Em T.

description: The foods are delicious. I love the ribs and fried fish. Hard to park near by and cash only.
author: Maggie Z.

description: Busy place with many Chinese locals.  Server rude and loud.  Only understood Chinese.  Great place to do family style lunch.  Liked clay pot Tofu and Seafood entree, as well as famous chicken wings!!
author: Sunny S.

description:
Growing up, the chicken wings were about $5 a box

This past summer (June 2015), it was about $9 a box...then eventually $10 later that year.

Now (Jan. 2016), it's about $11 a box

like other reviewers have said, there are about 12 ish wings in each box, give or take.

when $9, mom went "oh that's about a dollar each wing"
when $10, mom went "oh that's about a dollar each wing"
when $11, mom still went "oh that's about a dollar each wing"

Let's just say, these are highly addictive wings (the crispy flavorful skin makes each wing so so good).  I hope that it'll stay (less than) "about a dollar each wing" in the coming years
author: Maria C.

description:
My first two impressions of Capital Restaurant:

1.  This place is brightly lit.
2.  Wow, this is one of the cleanest restaurants I have ever seen in Chinatown.

I wouldn't eat off the floor, but by Chinatown standards this place is immaculate.  Even the restrooms were clean.  But in keeping with Chinatown tradition, I had to walk through the kitchen to get to the restroom.  I didn't do the ordering, so these are my best guesses as to what we ate after looking at the (probably incomplete) menu on Yelp.
