description: i love their salt and pepper chicken wings! not only are they fresh, but fried to perfection. it has a crunchy exterior with plenty of salt and pepper seasoning that is just to damm tasty. as a group of 6, we devoured two plates of these yummy wings. we also had an order of garlic dao miu (idk what its called in english). that was filled with garlic, not filled with grease and cooked to perfection. i know where to go when i'm in chinatown and looking for some good food!
author: Stella J.

description:
3.5 stars.

chicken wings are good as well as their tofu with meat sauce.  solid, cheap, chinese fare you can find in the touristy chinatown.
author: Helen T.

description: This is my aunt's favorite restaurant in Chinatown. Their quality is always consistently good and they have the BEST FRIED CHICKEN WINGS! Mmm. My mouth salivates a bit from the thought of it.
author: Samantha L.

description:
yummy, right near my work...big portions and fast service...

yes, the chicken wings are excellent, but i come here for the fried salty fish and pork....yummmmmmmmmmmmmmy!
author: Karen H.

description: This place is great. Cheap noodle dishes (#120 shanghai noodles especially) are super delicious.  The portion is huge! Also they have beer which is a plus. The service is also good. I will definitely be coming back soon.
author: Elliott B.

description: Huge portions, friendly service, authentic Cantonese food.  We ordered the famous salt and pepper wings, braised fish/tofu/shiitake clay pot, and Singapore rice noodles.  The husband was in heaven, and I thought it was pretty good too.  It was super-cheap as well, under $25 for 3 entrees.  Can't go wrong!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
New to Chinatown, I came to the Capital Restaurant on the recommendation of a store proprietor who I'd asked to suggest a restaurant. Sat at the counter and ordered the only combination plate for one, which included wanton soup, sweet & sour chicken, beef with broccoli, and egg roll and rice. I found the portions more than generous although the flavor seemed a little off to me. The sweet & sour chicken erred a little too far toward the "sweet," coming off like some sort of chicken-flavored candy. The beef lacked flavor altogether (and was a bit chewy). The wanton soup also lacked any real flavor, although it's possible the salty expectations set by my local Chinese takeout restaurant in Cambridge, Mass. influenced my opinion somewhat. And the egg roll looked like an overcooked appetizer from the frozen food section of the supermarket. Worst of all, the sauce from the chicken pooled around the plate with the water from the beef/broccoli making a big soupy mess on the place.

There must be something about this place as it filled up quick and I see a lot of good reviews, but unfortunately I don't have nearly enough time in town to get back for another go and this particular experience just didn't do that much for me. Not horrible by any means, but not particularly memorable, either.
author: Hugh R.

description: The wings are the best...fried, crispy with a sprinkle of salt. I usually don't go for Chinese food but everything we ordered was flavorful and not greasy. Service and cleanliness not bad, the decor is plain, prices are pretty good.
author: Amanda S.

description:
so my review may or may not be helpful in a conventional way, but you be the judge.

happy hour on friday got a little... drunk.  so why not go to capital and have a nice hot bowl of beef noodle soup.  two slurps into my AWESOME noodle soup, i notice that one of my friends starts to heave AT THE TABLE.  we quickly rush her out of the restaurant but only make it just outside the front door before the chunks start flying.  

BUT, the staff there were soooo nice, they didn't get mad at all, and oh by the way, we got to the restaurant just as they were closing and they were nice enough to serve us anyway!  so as much as i wanted to finish my amazing noodle soup, the capital crew was more than accommodating as we tended to our intoxicated friend.  

moral of the story: get the noodle soup, and in no way do i encourage going to capital drunk, but if you do, chances are that you'll be in good hands.
author: dan a.

description: The salt and pepper chicken wings are what everyone raves about here. Personally I felt the salt and pepper deep fried pork chops were better. They weren't fried as much as I like but still very good. The Mongolian beef was decent too. The taro root soup that came with our meal made everything feel down home and reminded me of the restaurants my parents like to frequent.
author: O'Shea J.

description:
Just average Chinese food for me. I didn't try their pancake/waffle stuff that some yelpers here mentioned though. 

The meal started with complimentary bitter melon soup. It was too bland. Then came the snow pea sprout with garlic sauce and Mongolian beef . 3 of us looked at each other wondering if our salty button didn't get activated or they just ran out of salt/soy sauce.  The very famous fried chicken wings were our finale. First bite reaction = oh yeah babie now we talkin. The crispness is just so right. When I got to my second wing, it almost didn't have salt on it. I looked up and saw my cousin pouring a stream of salt on his wing. We like salt :)

The place (and its kitchen) is actually pretty clean for Chinatown standard. But when a wait staff brought us some new plates. One of them still got fried rice stuck on it! Oh well, things happen.
author: Uarporn N.

description: Very good, authentic Chinese cooking - went there becuz my sister's family loves fried chicken wings - V. good if you like savory and crispy wings.  Servers - attentive (there were 15 of us at a big table) and accomodating.  All of the food was fresh. Pan fried assorted seafood noodles, grilled eggplant and (Szechuan) garlic sauce, chinese greens - all yummy!  Small, V. casual - comfy family place!
author: Angeli L.

description:
one word - YUM! bf and i had dinner here on tuesday night because he was craving chinese and i'm really glad he did! we did the menu A for two people. the only thing that i wasn't too keen on was the egg drop soup - but other than that everything was stellar. sweet and sour chicken and the beef with noodles were soooo good. 

place was pleasantly filled with other happy diners. glad to know that i have a GOOD chinese restaurant not too far from the apartment.
author: laura f.

description: really really good fried chicken wings.
author: Oleg H.

description:
I'd likely go back if I was in town again and craving Chinese food. Due to all the rave reviews here I ordered the salt & pepper chicken wings, and was not disappointed. Good good good. The tofu and mushrooms and vegetables was not too bad (I'm not a big tofu fan but wanted to try something different) and the vegetable fried rice was good. 

At about 7:30 on a Tuesday there were a decent number of Chinese and Caucasian folks (families, couples) in the main dining area, and me, an Australian, and a Kiwi (traveling separately) at the bar. 

By the way, you get about 10 wings with an order, and the other portions are pretty generous as well, so don't over-order!
author: Aaron B.

description: The salt and pepper fried chicken was as good as advertised.
author: Sam J.

description: Best salt n pepper chicken wing here in the whole wide city! It comes out fresh From the hot boiling oil, mmmm, you'll have to try. Also they have the salty "tong yuen". Other than that, they have specials on weekdays.
author: Monika T.

description:
this place is just below average.  the salt wings are good. they were most redeeming thing of the meal.  you have to ask for everything you want 2x.  the chicken in the stir fry dishes is fatty and not good quality meat.  the beef dish was strangely colored and i couldn't eat it.  we were told that locals eat there but we saw our fair share of tourists.  

i have never eaten in Chinatown before but if Capital is the standard.... i don't need to again.
author: Amalia S.

description: Thank you Capital for staying open for us to get our grub on in Chinatown--even despite the fact that you were closing. Your salt & pepper fried chicken wings hit the spot and gave us enough energy to  discover secret underground Chinatown dance clubs on a Sunday night!
author: Sue L.

description: The Salt and Pepper Chicken is to die for.  i love eatting at So's and San Tung in the sunset..............but when I need a chicken fixing near Chinatown..................Capital is the place to go.  Great food.
author: jason g.

description:
overall tasty food
my boyfriend and i went a bit crazy and ordered way too much food so it came out to around $60 for the 2 of us, but that's just because we over-ordered. it's actually quite affordable. It's also sanitary- I had to walk through the kitchen to use the bathroom but was reassured when I saw their kitchen was nice and clea.

we ordered the much talked about salt and pepper chicken wings and while they were good, they must have had MSG in them because not only were they addictive, I had a terrible stomachache after eating the leftovers of these bad boys.

This restaurant was not life changing or necessarily memorable, but I'd consider re-visiting it if I'm back in the neighborhood.
author: Felicity M.

description: Alright, this is a hole in a wall kind of place.  And its popular outside of the Chinese community.  How did I find out about it?  A Japanese waiter from Umi told me.  He was drooling just talking their famous chicken wings.  So we go there and see what its all about.  We walk in there with our Santa suits from Santacon.  The owner had to take a picture of us.  We got hella stares, especially from all the older Chinese ladies.  Couldn't help but laugh the whole time, but other than that, let's get to the food and service.  So I speak Cantonese and the waitress and I got chummy chummy already.  Joke with her, calling her my sista, and she was on it.  WAs super sweet, attentive, and even persuaded us to get two orders of wings and a round of beers.  The wings came and they were hella hot.  Salted just right, with jalapenos to spice it up a bit.  Super cripsy, juicy and yay, pretty good.  And its my favorite part of the wing too.  How could they go wrong then.  Then we ordered the pea pod leaves, tofu mushroom and beef chow fun.  The food came out fast, even with a packed house.  Beef chow fun was a bit bland, but nothing a little soy couldn't fix up.  The others dishes were good.  I enjoyed it, but honestly. . . Chinatown, trying to find parking just to have wings.  Hmm, maybe just a once a year visit will do.  Nothing I can't go thru a Popeye's tp get even more conveniently at.  Any who, and the last bit.  Have fun going to the restroom.  Its way in the back.  You have to walk thru the kitchen, pass all these short chefs, and then go down another level further into the pits to use the restroom.  Its probably some place you don't want to see where your food is prepared, but hell, the food is awesome anyways and I didn't get sick.  I think I won't complain about that tid bit.  Just suck it up and go.
author: Janice F.

description: The best salt and pepper fried chicken wings I've ever had.  Crispy and not too greasy.  A little bit of spice to them as well.  I had some kind of root with Chinese bacon and vegetables.  It was great and filling.  It goes without saying that the food is cheap.  Definitely worth the walk from the financial district for lunch.
author: Corey V.

description: This place was recommended to us by a local and I was skeptical at first. We ordered vegetable fried rice and black bean beef with white rice for take-out. The portions were huge and the three of us could barely finish it. The food tasted great. The rice was tasty but not overly salty. The beef was tender and had a good amount of spice and flavor.
author: Kevin K.

description:
How do you choose a favorite restaurant in Chinatown?

3 words:

Fried Chicken Wings........Fried Chicken WaaaAAAANGs!

After drinks from happy hour, what better to crave than some WaaaaAAAANgs! Crispy, delicious, and satisfies that grease crave when you need it.  I think it's like 16 wing for $7.

K, gotta give credit to their creamy prawns, fried rice...etc...but get them WaaaAAAANGs!

-J
author: Barbie D.

description: Man those chicken wings are bomb-diggity. You can see the msg cristals sparkling off of them! Good food all around. Just dont know if my heart can handle it
author: alex h.

description: Known for their deep fried salt and pepper chicken wings. Don't even think about getting them anywhere else! Mom will laugh and say you should have went to Capital, the Chinatown tried & true. Get it there and enjoy it with some chow fun/chow mein dishes.
author: Emily L.

description:
this review is by an ABC who loves eating in chinatown.  so theres no "lemon chicken" or house of nanking on my schedule of eats.

5 words.  salt and pepper chicken wings.  it's a plate full for around $5.  while you're at it, get 2 plates.

the good dishes we've found are:
- eggplant and beef
- claypot (this takes about 20/30 minutes, but worth the wait)
- salt and pepper shrimp (large juicy shrimp, not the crappy ones at other places)
- blackbean sauce catfish with tofu
- hot and sour soup.
author: Jason J.

description:
5 stars if you order the right stuff here. (dont order any of the roasted meats stuff over rice - they are not fresh). The stir fry lunches served over rice here is all good - beef and broccoli (any beef dish is good here - the beef is tender), mapo tofu, cashew chicken, then they have lunch specials on mondays, lamb curry must have, flounder fish sprinkled with almond flakes and tarter sauce on the side are a few good orders here. If you're open to trying aquired chinese tastes, get the salted fish fried rice with chicken - good flavor. For dinner and family style, their seafood options are very good - crab with ginger and scallion or the steamed fish. you'll get good food just like the more expensive chinese resturants but wihtout the expensive over charged prices. 
Like th eother reviewer said, its a real community institution here, lot of old timers and regulars come here, in fact thats how i know about this place, my father's friends come here after they've finished a game of cards across the street. Great place for casual quick lunch or good dinner for good price. and not to mention, the waitresses here all speak english and are always helpful, this is a huge plus for good chinese resturant.
author: Mai T.

description: Serves traditional-style Chinese food.  This place is small and fills up pretty quick.  I was a bit worried if this was a place for us until I saw a couple table occupied by non-Chinese patrons.  So, we settled down and browsed through the menu.  After a few arguments between my "tribe" members, we decided on the popular salt & pepper chicken, chicken foo yung, fried rice, and guy pan.  First, the salt & pepper chicken was very salty and not at all spicy.  Our fried rice was on the bland side ...but good match with the salt & pepper chicken!  ;)  ...foo yung was also a bit dull as well and the guy pan noodles were all stuck together in one big blob.  Together with the cash-only arrangement... this restaurant doesn't do it for me either.  Not in a bad way but I guess we really prefer the main-stream, touristy-type Chinese food.
author: Norm H.

description:
yes best salt and pepper chicken wings (with jalapneo peppers)!!!! i order wings from here for parties all the time. i bring wings from here when i visit someone at the hospital . . . . 

this should be in the SF Chronicle's 100 things to eat before you die
author: DANIEL T.

description: Down home Cantonese food. Best is their "lop jap fan" it's a mix of three cured meats that is cooked with rice in a clay pot.  It's very flavorful and you have to order in advance.  It also comes with a free vegetable.  And if you are really a home-style country person, ask them to make nung-jook where they take the clay pot back to the kitchen and burn the bottom of the pot and add either water or soup to it to make a crispy rice soup.  Gotta love it--and yeah, their chicken wings are the best.
author: Nancy H.

description: I love this place!!!  Salt and pepper chicken wings, and ginger scallion chicken are the best in the city!!!
author: Philip L.

description:
Love their CHICKEN WINGS!!!   Thin light coating and salt & pepper seasoning...so simple but soooo good.  I just wish that I live closer to this place and it's easier to get to (middle of chinatown).   

Other stuffs I've tried are their soups...they're ok..not bad.  But the chicken wing is definitely the star!!
author: Lan L.

description:
this place is very well known for their salt and pepper chicken, and i'm a regular for the chicken.  it's crispy, tasty, very well seasoned with a little spicyness.  they are very generous with the chicken!  

they have specials every day with very good price, give them a try, see if you will like them.
author: Sophia L.

description: I said I'd never Yelp about it, but here I am, sharing my biggest chicken secret with the world. Yes, these are some champion chicken wings.
author: miss b.

description: Their steamed fish is really good here. People say their fried chicken is cheap here. I have  never tried it though.
author: Janet Z.

description: This is a great hangout that serves one of the best salt and pepper fried chicken wings I've ever tasted.    I usually couple this with an order of the salted fish and chicken fried rice.     I usually drop by after church on Sundays for a quick lunch with friends.     Reasonable prices and good portions.
author: Don F.

description:
i'll keep my review short and sweet...

best chicken wings in chinatown!!!

period.
author: Ty L.

description: 4 stars for the salt/pepper fried chicken wings. YUM!!! Not by any means a fancy or even super clean restaurant. I also wouldn't give 4 stars for too many other items on the menu. It's a Chinese American restaurant/coffee shop in Chinatown. Decent and a few YUMMY items.... generally Cantonese dishes.... and waffles, eggs, coffee...
author: jane f.

description:
No thrills place in Chinatown.  I had a craving for fried chicken and the chicken salt and pepper wings satisfied them.  We also enjoyed the snow peas.  

Weird thing about this place is that to go to the bathroom, you can have to pass the kitchen.
author: Sim T.

description: This has been my standard favorite Chinese restaurant in town for years.  Everytime I take my friends and family here, it's a pure winner!  Potstickers are a must with rice vinegar and hot mustard.  The green beans are amazing.  They even have breakfast American style but I haven't tried that yet.  The staff is friendly.
author: Bryan L.

description: It's all about the wings.  Great flavor, crispy, salty, and carmelized,  good deal.  The rest is filler.
author: John T.

description: I've been eating here a better part of two decades now.  This is my definition of a hole in the wall (in the most complimentary way).  No ambience, handwritten menu items on the walls and bare bones.  However, the salt and pepper wings are awesome.  The chinese food is good and inexpensive.  The wait staff is friendly in that chinese mother sort of way.
author: My best mea l.

description: If you want Chinese salt and pepper fried chicken wings...get them here. So juicy...and soooo crunchy. All the other reviews about the wings are spot on. The other food is pretty standard Chinese fare, but those chicken wings are so memorable. We went there after the lunch rush and were the only people in the place for a little while. Service was good, although they didn't have the pickled green chili.?.
author: Michael D.

description:
if it weren't because of my co-workers, I would never have came here. It looks like a typical Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. But if you crave for some home-style cooking and a big claypot to share with a group, it might be a place to consider.
Some recommendations:
-- Fried chicken wings (we order this every single time)
-- Any type of clay pots (3-persons serving will feed at least 6-8 people)
-- sweet & sour pork chops 
-- Fried egg plants
-- Waffles for dessert (Yes, and they are delicious!!!)
 
And I do not recommend using their restroom, if you know what i mean...
author: S Y.

description: Went here with Kevin Liao. Amazing, especially with him picking the dishes. We got the crispy chicken wings with pepper, the crispy eggplant with pepper, the "live" whole tilapia (so fresh!), the egg tofu (wow), and a fish dish with eggplant. We were stuffed and went home with tons of leftovers for $60 for 3 people, including tip. Wow.
author: Josh B.

description: Capital has the best Chinese style salt and pepper chicken wings, they are so yummy and crispy.  We always get them to go, it's done in 15 minutes from the time the order is called in and take note that it's cash and carry.
author: Zoe P.

description: Old school classic of when I used to spend my weekends in SF Chinatown.  Probably ate here close to every week for a good portion of my life.  Dinner is more traditional home style cooking.  Chicken wings are always bomb.com.  What I also like is that they serve waffles.  O man just had a thought this very minute of salt n pepper chicken wings w/ waffles n a sh*t load of sizzurp.  Can we say Chinese Roscoe's Chicken and Waffles.  If someone else gets to it b4 i do lemme know how it is!
author: Rob N.

description: Salt and pepper wings (addicted for life). Great greens. Amazing prices. Huge menu. Weird restroom.
author: Jacinta H.

description: We did not get the salt and pepper chicken wings, although apparently we should have.  As such, all that stands out to me about my visit to this place is that some guy came over to us and asked us if we wanted a free glass of wine, because his wife ordered it and then realized she couldn't drink it because she was sick.  Suspicious in the extreme, except that his pitch almost immediately started with "My wife."
author: Sarah L.

description: Got the curry chicken.  1/2 the "chicken" was fat and the other 1/2 did not look nor taste like chicken.  Mystery meat.  I rarely eat in Chinatown, except Chef Gia's which is more North Beach, and this just confirms that I should stay away.
author: Jason D.

description: So I feel like a total loser cause my boyfriend and I made a reservation to come here. TOTALLY not necessary... for most of our meal we were the only people eating. This is a hole in the wall Chinese place - very bare and basic - almost looks like an old school coffee shop. The food was pretty good - certainly didn't blow me away though. We got the Combo #2 which consisted of wonton soup, egg rolls, beef fried rice and bbq pork chow mein. I wish we'd ordered the chicken wings everyone is raving about but we were still pretty full from our roasted chicken lunch at Zuni Cafe (sigh so good). They also serve waffles (random?) so the whole place smelled like batter. It was super cheap though - huge portions and all for about $10 a person.
author: Marina P.

description: I am a big fan of the Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings here. They are really good and cheap. The only thing is parking is impossible to find.. I usually do take out and eat them quickly before it gets cold.   Also, I tried the clams with black bean sauce they are also a winner..5 Stars for the Chicken wings.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Their salt and pepper chicken wings are the best.  Love them more than Sam Tung in the Sunset area.  That's the only thing I buy there.
author: John W.

description:
I had one of their lunch specials - shrimp and string beans with rice and it was very good, not exceptional but very good. The string beans were cooked perfectly. 

I have two complaints: very little gravy came with this dish and the portions were not big (but adequate). When I order a rice dish, I like lots of gravy to go with the rice and I had to scrape the bottom of the barrel to get enough to mix with my rice. The meal was well cooked, however, so I plan to return to try their other dishes. 

Tea and soup was included with the meal.

There are two lunch menu specials - a Chinese one and an American one. The American special includes ice cream for dessert.

I don't know what the purpose of serving American food in a Chinese restaurant is but it's done here.
author: John C.

description: This place has incredibly good salt and pepper chicken wings. Everything else on the menu is good, too, though I'd skip ordering a waffle. Really, who orders a waffle at a Chinese restaurant? I actually have no idea what else I've eaten here, as I'm always with people who speak Cantonese, and I can't understand a thing they're ordering. However, you could almost certainly order randomly and still be happy, provided you're truly omnivorous. Just make sure you get the wings!
author: Michael G.

description: Change of ownership has occurred at one of my favorite restaurants in Chinatown :( It's sad because the new ownership SUCKS! They must have hired new chefs because the quality of the food has really gone down the drain, which is why i don't recommend anyone to go eat at this place anymore, DON'T GO!
author: Q W.

description: OMG!!! their Fried Chicken is GOOD!!! its yummy and its one of there BEST dishes and their dinner is great too...I JUST LOVE THE FRIED CHICKENN!!!! thinking of it makes me drool...lolx!!! anyways if the chicken get cold its still CRUNCHY!!! and stuff, and don't know how they cook it but its not dry at all...like some people that fry them!!!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Awesome place for salted fish fried rice and salt and pepper chicken wings. -1 star for the dirtiness.
author: Jimmy C.

description: This place is alrite, but it has kinda gone down the hill over the years just like all the other good restaurants. A little bit at least, it's just not as good as it used to be. On a good day I would give it a 3.8 star, but over all it's a 3. Salt and Pepper chicken is pretty good like everybody say it is, everything else is average/decent, nothing special, and it's not that cheap considering the quality. But they keep the place pretty clean and cozy, so it's pretty good to sit down and have a comfortable meal, try them.
author: Wes Z.

description: I get the feeling you have to be chinese or have a chinese friend in the know if you're gonna go to this joint. The menu has a thousand dishes on it but they can't all be good. The wings were really good. The concrete gray wonton noodle soup was not so much. It looked like food that only Oliver Twist would get served.
author: Andy L.

description: Their salt and pepper wings are very good.  We did take-out and I'm pretty sure I'm not going to actually eat-in there because while I was waiting, I saw a member of the waitstaff walking around smacking flies on the walls and wiping them up with a napkin.  Um, gross.
author: Michelle C.

description: The gentleman I sat next to at the counter recommended the chicken wings after I spotted the hard to come by favorite (at least where I'm from) on the menu listed outside on the side walk.  I ordered a lunch special of flounder & eggplant, which was supposed to come with soup, but may have been inadvertently forgotten.  Nonetheless, there was plenty of food.  My friend had the spare rib with green beans.  I stole glances at the plate in front of another woman at the counter; she had some shrimp & dumpling looking feast.  Lots of locals were dining here, thus my decision to venture into the spot off the beaten path.  Another local patron made me promise not to disclose the one of a kind find.  Note, you do have to travel through the kitchen to access the tiny bathroom after downing a pot of hot tea.
author: sara l.

description: Salt & pepper chicken wings ROCK!  Be prepared to eat some hole-in-the-wall style Chinese cuisine.
author: Kiet D.

description: After reading the reviews, we decided to go to Capital Restaurant, but other than the salt and pepper chicken wing appetizer, which came to the table hot and crispy, we were disappointed with the dishes we ordered, especially Twice Cooked Pork.  I didn't expect a fully authentic treatment -- this not being a Szechuan restaurant -- but nor should the interpretation veer so far off course as to be unrecognizable!  The service was fine, and the portions were quite large.
author: Harry L.

description: i will be back for sure. this place is not bad.  6 of us on a table having a feast. i want to say like 6 great dishes and the bill came out to under $60.  i dont know in your book, but ill take that deal any day. plus any chinese restaurant that serves pea sprouts is a winner.
author: Ricky Y.

description: This is a small no nonsense chinese restaurant in the middle of Chinatown. Tried the place after I saw the chicken wings reviews on yelp. Naw.... the wings did not work for me, they did not taste good and were cooked in oil that had a strange taste to it, probably they had been frying stuff in it over and over agin. The side eggplant order was swimming in oil as well. Definitely did not enjoy my meal at this place
author: Sandy p.

description: Tasty and reasonably priced. Chicken wings were good but I wouldn't rave about them as much as others on Yelp. I've had better in San Diego.
author: Chris P.

description: I don't write a lot of reviews in general, and I hate to write bad reviews, but this place was pretty bad.  We ordered the fried squid, spinach and garlic, and salted fish fried rice.  The vegetables were OK, as was the rice, but the squid was very greasy and the sauce that came with it was bad.  Probably the worst meal I've had at a restaurant in SF in the past couple years.
author: Mark M.

description: Loved it, great Chinatown find. Really nice service.
author: David G.

description: everyone talks about the salt and pepper chicken wings but what about all the other items on the menu that are fried and covered with that salt and pepper stuff: fish, shrimp, pork ribs, tofu, eggplant. i think that if i offered them my hand they would prepare it with that magical fairy dust and i would happily eat it.
author: Rowena M.

description: i love good, cheap, chinese food. the lunch specials over rice are an excellent deal. they offer a pretty good selection of rice dishes including your average chinese fast food entrees like beef broccoli and kung pao chicken to good ol chinese comfort food such as tomato beef or egg and shrimp over rice. plus, they usually give you a big bowl of the house soup.  but the main reason i usually make the trek out here for lunch is the salt and pepper fried chicken wings. very tasty and sooo addictive. crispy wings tossed in salt and white pepper powder, with jalepenos and green onions, makes your mouth water and wanting more.
author: Steven L.

description: The chicken wings are awesome, though a little too salty. Other dishes are okay, not that great. The service is fairly good.
author: warakant j.

description: came here on saturday night with my friend who lives in chinatown and he said if we go here that we have to try the fried chicken wings.  they certainly didn't disappoint.  they were fried to perfection and had just the right around of salt and not too greasy either.  i was thoroughly impressed.  we also had some beef chow fun and general's chicken which were both pretty good but nothing too special.  if you're in the area stop by and give it a try, you will love it!
author: Landon Y.

description: Recommended by my mother in laws coworker, we came here on Chinese new year 2010.... Place was packed so we thought we were in for some of the best Chinese food ever.....Ya not so much. Poor service our waitress didn't speak any English so every time we asked for anything (like a straw) she would just walk away... more funny then anything else..... we never received our steamed rice. and there were six of us we all ordered something different to share, The food was so bland no flavor!!! the only saving grace was there chicken wings..Next time we visit we will order the chicken wings TO GO!!!
author: Raquel V.

description: Great wings, noodles and dumplings. The staff was great, and they made a special dish for my son who has allergies. I am looking forward to going back!
author: jeff b.

description: I was crazing Chinese food for lunch. As my office is on the border of China Town, I thought it would be easy. BUT, most of the cheaper places get terrible reviews. So, I decided to try the highest rated one (it has 4 stars, not bad)! I walked over, even though it's lunch, to check it out. Looked ok from the inside, so I decided to order. I ordered the Dinner Special 1, which is beef and brocoli, pineapple chicken, rice, dumpling soup and a fortune cookie. It took about 25 minutes for the food. Not terrible, but I saw people being seated, ordering and receiving the food before I got mine. So, I was a little put off. But, that wouldn't have been enough to warrant my 2 stars. The food is just OK in my mind, nothing special or memorable. Everybody did rave about the chicken wings, and I saw a couple of orders, and they looked better then what I got, so maybe I just ordered the wrong thing. I won't be going back to find out...
author: Joel R.

description: Took the family ( 10 & 16 yr old).  Service was good and fast.  Waitress was helpful. Best Chinese meal we've ever had.  Huge portions.  Go for the salt & pepper chicken wings.  Lo mein, sesame chicken, sizzling chicken with black beans, all good!
author: Doug K.

description: Just get the salt and pepper wings.  The rest of dishes there are good, but what makes Capital shine is their signature wing dish.  The skin is crispy with salt and pepper stuck onto it, the meat is tender and juicy (oily), and the price is very reasonable.  Order other stuff as complements, but definitely try the wings.
author: Alex E.

description: We stopped by before the Chinese New Year's parade and had a wonderful meal.  My mother-in-law ordered a scallop dish that was tasty, and cooked to perfection.  I had the mongolian beef chow mein noodles, also very tasty.  My husband ordered the salt and pepper wings becasue we had to see what the fuss was about - they deserve all the accolades they get!  The service great, very friendly and considerate, despite being so busy stopped by a few times to make sure we had everything we needed.  We'll definitely be back!
author: L C.

description: They have the best salt n pepper chicken wings in town.  They put KFC's hot wings to shame.  Everyone is really nice and they serve home style chinese dishes like the ones my mom use to make.  If there's a rare dish that you don't see on their menu, you can always request them to make it for you.  You can even bring in your own stuff and ask them to cook it for you.  I once saw a man who brought in his own abalone and asked them to cook it for him; they only charged him for the veggies and tofu they used to cook the abalone.
author: Kate L.

description: Capital Restaurant is an excellent cheep, small, and delicious find in Chinatown.  It is a bare bones place with wooden tables and chairs and a Formica or wood floor.  The waitresses are very nice.  The prices are rock bottom.  Pot stickers have skins that are crispy golden on one side and not too thin or thick and not doughy on the other; the filling of your typical ground pork, ginger, and cabbage filling which is excellent.  The Capital plate (barbecued pork, which is tender and marinaded in Honey and Chinese five spices, egg rolls that are crispy with fresh vegetables, and fried prawns that are greasless, crispy, and succulent.)  The sweet and sour sauce was well balanced.  Round everything off with a Ching Dao and you cannot go wrong.  The bill, which also included my mother's red wine was $21.20.  So, for rock bottom prices, quality service, and excellent food, Capital Restaurant cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.
